6

Experiment: be the optimizer

You will have a set of inputs (chemical properties of wines) 
and a set of outputs (rating of each wine)

For each input, you will need to set the 
β
 parameter to 
minimize the squared difference between your 
predicted 
rating and the actual rating

Move the slider for each variable left or right to change 
parameter settings

7

https://mimno.infosci.cornell.edu/info2950/interactive/wine.html
 

8

Each of these is a 
coefficient in a 
regression


Quality ~ intercept + 
fixed_acidity + 
volatile_acidity + ...

https://mimno.infosci.cornell.edu/info2950/interactive/wine.html
 

9

How do we know this 
is the right coefficient 
for fixed acidity, 
instead of 
somewhere to the 
left or right of it?

Multivariable Gradient Intuition

1.
What is the smallest squared 
error you can find?


2.
Which sliders move the points 
more or less?

The “best” coefficients are 
the ones that, together, 
minimize MSE

scales: 
normalize
 with z-scores

density

total sulfur

17

How do you minimize 
squared error?

18

Before, we talked about using 
calculus to do this by hand (for single 
variable linear regressions)

What is the maximum value of 
output f(x)?

output 
f(x)

input x

19

The derivative is a hint: which way 
would you go to increase f(x)?

Derivative (slope) at this 
point is 
negative
, which 
means that decreasing 
x
 
will make f(x) bigger

20

output 
f(x)

input x

The derivative is a hint: which way 
would you go to increase f(x)?

Derivative (slope) at this 
point is 
negative
, which 
means that decreasing 
x
 
will make f(x) bigger

21

output 
f(x)

input x

The derivative is a hint: which way 
would you go to increase f(x)?

When the derivative 
(slope) is zero, f(
x
) will 
decrease in either 
direction

22

output 
f(x)

input x

The derivative is a hint: which way 
would you go to increase f(x)?

If we go too far, the 
derivative will be 
positive, meaning we 
can 
get a larger f(
x
) by 
increasing 
x

23

output 
f(x)

input x

Gradient is a hint in multiple 
directions

The slope is steep in the 
East-West direction, 

but flat in the 
North-South direction

24

Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD)

Derivative is 
negative, so we 
should reduce 
x
, 
but how much?

25

output 
f(x)

input x

SGD: move 
β
 in a direction 
specified by the gradient

Slope still 
negative, but 
less so:


"keep going in 
that direction, 
but slow down"

26

output 
f(x)

input x

SGD: "step size" or "learning rate" 

is important

If you take a big 
step you may 
overshoot:


"Whoa, too far! 
back up a bit"

27

output 
f(x)

input x

SGD: "step size" or "learning rate" 

is important

Overshooting 
can lead to 
oscillation and 
blowup! 


28

output 
f(x)

input x

Too small a step 
and it will take 
forever to improve

SGD: "step size" or "learning rate" 

is important

29

output 
f(x)

input x

31

Takeaways on gradients

●
“Stochastic gradient descent” is used to find 
minima / maxima for complicated models (e.g. 
multivariable regression)


○
choose a 
learning
 rate to do this efficiently


○
this is the core of modern machine 
learning
!

https://towardsdatascience.com/batch-mini-batch-stochastic-gradient-descent-7a62ecba642a

35

Variables can interact

"Vitamin C and vitamin E are possibly the best example of 
a skincare power couple as they each enhance the effects 
of the other. For example, vitamin C helps to regenerate 
vitamin E, making it more readily available to protect the 
skin from free radicals. 
Vitamin E returns the favor by 
increasing the action of vitamin C four-fold (4x)
 
[19][20]."


https://www.sciencebecomesher.com/skincare-ingredients-that-work-better-together/

36

Variables can interact

"Vitamin C and vitamin E are possibly the best example of 
a skincare power couple as they each enhance the effects 
of the other. For example, vitamin C helps to regenerate 
vitamin E, making it more readily available to protect the 
skin from free radicals. 
Vitamin E returns the favor by 
increasing the action of vitamin C four-fold (4x)
 
[19][20]."

Results are 
not 
linear in C + E!

https://www.sciencebecomesher.com/skincare-ingredients-that-work-better-together/

37

Multivariable Regressions

●
Our interpretations (both for linear regression 
and logistic regression) have assumed that:

○
increasing x
1
 by one unit only affects y, so 
the only source of an effect due to x
1
 is 
captured by 
β
1

Multivariable Regressions

●
Our interpretations (both for linear regression 
and logistic regression) have assumed that:

○
increasing x
1
 by one unit only affects y, so 
the only source of an effect due to x
1
 is 
captured by 
β
1


●
What if this isn’t the case? What if changing 
x
1
 
also has something to do with 
x
2
?

Introducing: 
Interactions

●
“Interactions” in regression math are when 
different 
x
’s should be considered 
together
 


●
Interactions
 (in math) ≈
 Intersectionality 
(in life)

DeGraffenreid v. General Motors (1976)

●
GM did not hire Black women before 1964


●
In the early 1970s recession, GM did layoffs by 
seniority 
→
 all the Black women were laid off


●
5 Black women sued GM over discrimination by 
gender 
and
 race


●
Unsuccessful because the court didn’t know how to 
deal with the 
intersection
 of gender and race 

https://www.vox.com/the-highlight/2019/5/20/18542843/intersectionality-conservatism-l
aw-race-gender-discrimination
 

41

https://www.vox.com/the-highlight/2019/5/20/18542843/intersectionality-conservatism-l
aw-race-gender-discrimination
 

42

-
Judge Harris Wangelin’s ruling against the plaintiffs


DeGraffenreid v. General Motors (1976)

●
Interactions
 (in math) ≈
 Intersectionality 
(in life)

 

●
y = teaching evaluations


Keep an eye out for mid-semester teaching 
evaluations for TAs!


They’ve worked really hard and any praise for 
them via feedback would be appreciated :)

Interpreting Regressions

●
If 
no interactions
, interpret each different x
i
 
separately

Outliers & Oddities


●
If 
have interactions
, interpret by plugging in 
values for different combinations of x
i

○
Predict Outcome | Outliers & Oddities

58

Recall that interactions are like 
mathematical intersectionality.

Does it make sense to use interactions on 
the season dummies summer (x
2
), fall (x
3
), 
and/or winter (x
4
)?

59

琀
琀

Dummies x Interactions

Does it make sense to use interactions on the 
season dummies x
2
, x
3
, and/or x
4
? 

No, because the seasons are mutually exclusive: 

x
2
* x
3 
=0, x
2
* x
4 
=0, x
3
* x
4 
=0.  Including a 0 term in your 
regression does not add any meaning to your model!

●
We expect ice cream with mustard to yield the lowest (61.3) enjoyment, ice 
cream with chocolate sauce to yield 93 enjoyment, hot dog with mustard to 
yield 89.6 enjoyment, and hot dog with chocolate sauce to yield 65.3 
enjoyment.  We propose bringing ice cream with chocolate sauce to the 
picnic to maximize enjoyment.

Multivar Regression: Interactions

●
These examples were for one binary covariate 
against another binary covariate


●
You can do interactions for any pair of covariate 
types (categorical x categorical, continuous x 
categorical, continuous x continuous)


●
How to interpret continuous interactions?
  More 
complicated, 
need to plot

Multivariable Regression

●
We’ve told you that Vitamin C increases the efficacy 
of Vitamin E when they’re both ingredients in 
skincare products. 


●
How would you model this? 

○
y = customer satisfaction of product (
continuous
)

○
x
1
 = _________ (
data type
), x
2
 = _______ (
data type
)

○
Model: y ~ ______________


83

琀
琀

1
*x
2

●
When there is both vitamin C and vitamin E in the product, we predict customer 
satisfaction to be the highest, at 6.0 + 54.0*1 + 41.5 *1- 6.0*1 = 95.5.

●
When there is no vitamin C and no vitamin E in the product, we predict customer 
satisfaction is lowest, at 6.0 + 54.0*0 + 41.5*0 - 6.0*0 = 6. 

●
When there is only vitamin C in the product, we predict customer satisfaction is 
6.0 + 54.0*1 + 41.5*0 - 6.0*0 = 60. When there is only vitamin E in the product, we 
predict customer satisfaction is 6.0 + 54.0*0 + 41.5*1 - 6.0*0 = 47.5.

This is why we don’t just 
read off the coefficient to 
“summarize” interactions!

How to run regressions with 
interactions in Python?

90

How to run regressions with 
interactions in Python?

●
Google it!


https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45828964/how-to-add-interaction-term-in-python-sklearn
 

91

How to run regressions with 
interactions in Python?

●
A few different ways to make the interaction:

○
Manually multiply two columns in your dataframe 
and include that third column in your X input

○
Use PolynomialFeatures() from sklearn

○
Use another package (like 
patsy
) to use ~ format


●
Then, run LinearRegression().fit(X,y) as usual

92

Takeaways

●
Interactions ≈ Intersectionality


●
Use “interaction plots” to determine whether you need 
an interaction term in your regression model


●
Interpret regressions with interactions by plugging in 
different values of the x’s and 
predicting outcomes
. Do 
not rely on reading the coefficients to summarize the 
effects!

121

Spearman Correlations

Monotonicity

https://statistics.laerd.com/statistical-guides/spearmans-rank-order-correlation-statistical-guide.php
 

●
To have a monotonic relationship, one of the following 
must
 be true:


○
As the value of one variable 
increases
, the other 
variable value 
increases


○
As the value of one variable 
increases
, the other 
variable value 
decreases

Spearman vs Pearson: Similarities

●
Both correlations yield coefficients between 

-1 and 1


●
Higher coefficient magnitude 
→
 stronger 
relationship between variables

146

Takeaways on rank transforms

●
Ranking your data can be useful, depending on 
the application


●
If you want to compare rankings, use Spearman 
correlation to understand the monotonicity 
relationship between variables


●
Monotonicity != Linear relationships


●
And...
